body_text.text: Allcrgic rhinitis and comnion cold arc airway diseases charzictcrizcd by mucosal processcs of inflammation. Nasal challenge and lavagc tcchniques havc successfully becn cmploycd to study these processcs. Thc nasal pool-device is onc challenge and lavage technique that compared with others may havc certain advantagcs: Hcnce, the technique allows concomitant challenge and lavagc of a large and defined mucosal surface area for a selected pcriod of time. Furthermore, thc employability of the nasal pool-dcvicc makes it suitablc for challenge and lavagc in children. Important characteristics, including microvascular and cellular indices, of the nasal mucosa in health and disease may be well cxamincd using thc nasal pool-dcvicc and other challenge and lavagc tcchniqucs. The microvascular and epithelial exudation of bulk plasma (mucosa cxudation) is of key interest in airway inflammation. Proinflammatory factors e.g., histamine, lcukotrienes, bradykinins, and select cytokincs including TNFa, produce extravasation of bulk plasma by action on the endothelial cells of post-capillary venulcs. Promptly, thc cxtravasated plasma then movcs up between the epithelial cells and crcatcs transicnt separation of the tight junctions between these cells so that ubiquitous paracellular pathways for the clcarancc of plasma into thc airway lumen arc rcdily created. The luminal entry of plasma, although involving movcmcnt of largc protcins such as a,-macroglobulin, is non-injurious as it lcavcs thc skuctiirc nT tlic cpitliclium intact. Furthermorc, the integrity of the mucosa as an absorption bamcr is uncompromiscd. Indeed, in sustained airway inflammation mucosal exudation may even be associated with a rcduccd absorption permeability. Thc physiological, non-injurious mcchanisrns involved in extravasation and luminal entry of bulk plasma in animal and human airways are the basis for thc proposal that mucosal exudation should be considcrcd a major first line defence mechanism of the airway mucosa. Mucosal exudation of bulk plasma is induccd by challenges that activate discasc-likc inflammtion, e.g. allergens, isocyanates, and common cold viruses. Accordingly, incresed concentrations of plasma proteins in airway mucosal surface liquids have been demonstrated in allergic rhinitis and common cold, as well as in nasal polyposis, asthma, and chronic bronchitis. The bulk plasma exudate has a widespread and intriguing distribution in these disease: The lamina propria, the basement membrane, the airway epithelium and the mucosal suface are thus furnished by potent plasma-derived peptides and proteins. Thereforc, the mucosal macromolecular milieu in airway inflammation would be dramatically different from that of the normal mucosa. In addition to its function as a mucosal defence mechanism, the plasma exudate may be a pathogenetic factor in these airway disease: Physical properties of the plasma exudate may e.g., interfere with the normal hydration of the airway and impair mucociliary transport. Furthermore, the plasma pcptide and protein systems may sustain airway inflammation. Morcover, in allergic rhinitis and common cold, an exudativc hypcrresponsiveness may develop: Histamine thus produccs grcatcr plasma cxudation responses in on-going allergic and infectious rhinitis than in control situations. This increased proclivity of thc airway subepithelial microcirculation to rcpond with plasma exudation may be a kcy fcaturc of inflammatory airway discasc. The exudative hyperresponsiveness may not be explained by an incrcased absorption pcrmability of the airway mucosa, as this may be rcduccd in allergic rhinitis and unaffected in common cold. The microcirculation is but one of the mucosal end-organs that may dcvclop a hyperresponsivseness in airway inflammation. The lumina entry plasma may reflect the intensity and time coursc of airway inflammatory proccsscs. Accordingly, thc cfficacy of anti-inflammatory treatment in rhinitis and asthma may be exprcsscd as dccreascd amounts of plasma proteins on the mucosal surface. In human airways, in contrast to animal airways, this cffcct appears to be mediated almost exclusively by effects on the inflammatory process rather than by pharmacological actions dircctly on thc microcirculation. In summary, mucosal exudation of plasma is a key further of airway inflammation in rhinitis and asthma. The proccss indicates the inflammatory nature of thesc diseases and it providcs an opportunity for quantitative meansurement of the inflammatory involvcment. Mucosal exudation is primarily a dcfcncc mechanism, but in rhinitis and asthma the plasma exudate with its potcnt peptidcs and proteins has a multipotential role in the perpetuation of airway inflammation. The bulk naturc and the widespread mucosal distribution (lamina propria, epithelium, and airway surface) of the plasma exudatc indicatcs that plasma with all its potent protein systems may dramatically dctcrmine the biologically active molecular milieu of the mucosa. For example, plasma-dcrived products (e g fibrinogen and fibroncctin) may decide cellular function and traffic, %-macroglobulin distributes and targets several cytokines, and an endlcss number of plasma-derivcd peptides are produced (clotting, complcment, and kinin systems). The plasma exudation proces~ may thus influence cellular activities and the distribution and flux of cellular products within the mucosa and onto the airway surface. In agrcement, wc have demonstrated that the mucosal output of L-6 in seasonal allergic rhinitis is dramatically increascd by a simple challenge with an exudative concentration of histamine, suggesting that the mucosal exudation process alone can incrcasc the concentration of this cytokine in airway mucosal surface liquids. Increased concentrations of cellular products in mucasal surface liquids may thus be due to increased cellular production and rclease, increased transport to the mucosa surface by the plasma exudation process, or a combination of thcsc processcs. Trcatmcnts that rcduce the cellular inflammatory processes ( e g gluwrticoids) rcducc thc conccntrations of plasma proteins in airway mucosal suface liquids. We have further demonstrated that budesonide rcduus thc numbcr of eosinophils in the nasal mucosa togcthcr with the mucosal output of albumin and fibrinogen in scasonal allcrgic rhiiiitis, and that loratadine reduces markcdly allcrgcn challcngcinduced mucosal output of %-macroglobulin and modcratcl y tryptase in exerimcntal acutc allcrgic rhinitis. Howcvcr, thc anti-exudative effects of antihistamines, in contrast to that of glococorticoids, may not be well maintained in nasal allergic disease conditions. In summary, the nasal mucosa is a suitable part of the airways whcrc wcll-controllcd challenge and lavage techniques can be used for studics of airway inflammation. Cellular products and indices of plasma exudation can be analysed in the lavagc fluids to detcrminc cellular activation and tissue involvment, respcctivcly, in diffcrcnt diseascs. The plasma exudation process may also influence cellular activitics and thc flux of cellular products into airway surface liquids. These possibilities emphasise the importance of in vivo obscrvations in studics of airway inflammation. body_text.text: Normally quite markcd and rapid clinical improvements and changes in lung functions are seen already at very low daily doscs of inhaled steroids (around 100 pg) even in children with moderate and severe asthma. These improvements in lung function and symptoms precede and reach a pleteau before the reduction in reponsiveness. The additional improvcment in symptoms with increasing doses is rather small, and oflen in takes an additional four-fold increase in dose to produce an additional significant effect on symptoms or peak flow measurements. Low doses of inhaled steroids also have a significant effect on airway hyper responsiveness or lower airways functions. However, the dose response curve of these parameters in less steep so that it is possible to demonstrate a significant log linear dose response relationship over a much wider dose range on these parameteri in childrcn with moderate and severe asthma. A daily dose of 400 ,ug budesonide producing about 80% of the maximum achievable protection against exercise i n d u d ashma. This indicates that the vast majority of school children can achieve optimal symptom control on quite low daily doses of inhaled steroids equivalent to 100-200 pg budcsonide, whereas somewhat higher doses and longer treatment is requircd to control hyperreactivity as assessed by protection against exercise induced asthma. An optimally controlled asthma child lives a normal life without any restrictions in physical activity and without any asthma symptoms or exacerbations. Lung functions arc normal and incrcasc ovcr time as in healthy non astmatic children.

body_text.text: Furthermore, the child experiences no side effects from the treatmcnt. This level of control probably requires that the bronchial reactivity is within the normal range and that the inflammatory changes in the airwiays are minimal. Several studics have shown that asthma severity and the impact that the asthma disease has upon the daily life of the child arc often markedly underestimated because it is difficult to correctly assess symptoms and the extent to which the child has adapted its lifcstyle to avoid symptoms. As a consequence many children are undertreated, optimal asthma control is not achieved and inhalcd corticostcroids are either not prescribed or prescribed after the asthmatic condition has developed for many years. Recent findings suggest that if treatment with inhaled corticosteroids is not initiated until the asthmatic condition has developed for several years it is more difficult to achieve continuous, optimal long term control than if this treatment is introduccd early after the debut of asthma symptoms. In one study an inverse relationship between the duration of asthma at the start of budesonide treatment and the annual increase in F%V, during budcsonide therapy was seen. After 3 years of budesonide trcatmcnt childrcn who started this therapy later than 5 years after the onset of asthma had significantly lower FEV, (96%) than the children who received budesonidc within the first 2 ycars after thc onset of asthma (101%).

body_text.text: Furthermore, the children who started budcsonidc early required lowcr doses of budesonide to be well controlled than the children, who startcd budesonide aftcr more than 5 years delay. This and other findings suggest that early intervention with inhaled corticosteroids facilitates (is a precondition for?) long term optimal asthma control. This suggests that early use of inhaled corticosteroids may have a modifiing effect upon the natural course of the disease. In addition it reduces the risk of undertreatment and ensures normal growth of lung functions.

Thcrcforc, more studies are required in such patients before final conclusions about thc possibility of long tcrm supprcssivc effects can be made. Today 3.700 contact allergens have been described and new ones are identified every year. Usually. a formulated product has caused contact eczema in an exposed individual and when he or she is patch tested with the product as well as its ingredients the new allergen is identified. It is crucial to use analytically defied chemicals, to avoid testing in a patient with current eczema, to use serial dilution tests to defiie a threshold of sensitivity and to prove by testing non-exposed subjects that the test preparation is non irritant. Corricosteroidssystemic or topicalare an essential medication for allergic diseases. Interestingly, they are themselves also capable of causing allergic reactions. Systemic corticosteroids may cause a variety of allergic symptoms from flare to anaphylaxis-like reactions. The latter have been ccnsidered to be usually caused by pseudoallergic mechanisms and they are also rare. The most common allergy to corticosteroids is contact allergy and it has not been shown to be associated with 'anaphylac toid reactions. In several studies corticosteroids have been shown to be common contact allergens. Corricosteroid that has caused most patch test reactions is tixocortol pivalate. Tixocortol pivalate reactions reveal contact allergy to hydrocortisone, the most commonly used corticosteroid. by allergic cross-reactivity. Tixocortol pivalate itself is not used as dermatologic preparation and sensitization through contact to it is therefore not likely. Other corticosteroids that often cause patch reactions are budesonide and hydrocortisone butyrate. Contact allergies to Compositue plants may cause a severe and frequently chronic dermatitis. Repeated exposure over a number of years may cause severe intractable dermatitis afFccting the patient throughout the year. The major allergens responsible are sesquiterpene lactones. A curing agent or hardener is added to complete the polymerization reaction, and many of e.g. epoxy rcsin hardeners are sensitizers: aliphatic polyarnines (triethylene tetramine), cycloaliphatic polyamines (isophorone diamine), aromatic amines (diaminodiphenyl methane), acid anhydrides (methyIhexahydrophthalic anhydride), isocyanates. etc. Sensitizing additives include inhibitors (e.g. hydroquinone), initiators (benzoyl peroxide), plasticizers (phthalates), flame retilrdants (bromine containing compounds), heat stabilizers (epoxidized oils), antioxidants (4-ten.-butylcatechol), ultraviolet light absorbers (benzophenones), and colourant.. (organic pigments). -Synthetic resins and plastics are the third most common cause (after rubber chemicals and met;ils) of occupational allergic dermatoses in Finland. There has been a search for a more convenient marker to differentiate between Thl and Th2 cells than the laborious methods based on analysis of their cytokine production. CD30 has been claimed to be a surface marker for Th2 cells (Del Prete et al. FASEB J 9:81, 1995) allowing flow cytomelry analysis of cells for recognition of Th2-mediated immune reactions in different diseases. CD30 is a 120-kDa molecule originally defined as a tumor-specific antigen in Hodgkin and Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's disease. We have found that not only Th2 cells but also Thl and Tho cells have a high CD30 expression after activation (Bengtsson et al. Leukoc Biol 58683, 1995). Our observation has recently been confirmed by another group (Hamann et al. J Immunol 156:1387, 1996) . Thus, CD30 expression cannot be used to discriminate between human Thl-and Th2-like cells.

Recently, considerable progress has been made in the understanding of the mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of atopic disease. Allergen-specific T-cell responses in atopic patients are dominated by the T helper (Th) 2 subset, which produces, among other cytokines, high levels of I L 4 , IL-5 and IG13, and low levels of IFN-y. IL-4 and IL-13 induce IgE synthesis by human B cells whereas, IFN-y, which is predominantly produced by Thl cells and CD8+ T cells has inhibitory effects. IL-4, but not IL-13, also induces naive CD4+ T cells to differentiate into Th2 cells. Furthermore, IL-3 and IG5 produced by activated allergen-specific Th2 cells account for growth, differentiation and survival of eosinophils, which are implicated in lung damage associated with asthma.

body_text.text: In addition, combinations of IL-13, IL-4 and ILlO produced by Th2 cells synergize with c-kit ligand in promoting the expansion of mast cells, which together with basophils, are the main effector cells in the immediate allergic response. This information indicates that allergy is a Th2 cell dieease and that Th2 :ytokines account for the hallmarks of the allergic inflammatory response. Therefore, inhibition of the biological activities of allergen-specific Th2 cells, or intervention of differentiation of these cells could provide an efficient way to intervene in allergic dieease.

body_text.text: It w i l l also be shown that IL4-driven differentiation of Der PI-specific Th2 cells obtained from skin biopsies following Der PI challenge can be redirected into a Tho phenotype by stimulating the T cells in the presence of IL-12 or through co-stimulation via SLAM, which is a novel receptor involved in T-cell activation. The clinical implications of these findings will be discussed. Subpopulations of effector CD4+ helper T cells that produce distinct sets of cytokines are important in various infectious, allergic and autoimmune diseases. Thl cells secrete L-2 and IFN-y, and Th2 cells produce IL4, IL-5 and IL-lo. These polarized subsets of differentiated helper T cells arise from a common a naive CD4+ T cell precursor that produces small amounts of IL-2 and no detectable IFN-y or IL-4. In order to gain insights into the molecular basis of subset-specific cytokine gene expression, we have analyzed cytokine gene transcription and transcription factor activation in Thl and Th2 murine helper T cell clones and in bulk populations of TCR-transgenic T cells as they undergo subset differentiation in virro. Our findings suggest that differences in NFKB and Stat6 (lL-4Stat) activation are related tL differences in T cell subset phenotype and differentiation.

body_text.text: In studies with long-term cloned T cell lines, Thl cells were defmed as those which produce IL-2 and IFN-y but no IL-4 mRNA by RT-PCR. Th2 cells were conversely defined as those producing IL4, but no IL-2 or IFN-ymRNA. We have found that NFKB activation is differentially regulated in these two types of clones. TCR stimulation of Thl clones induces a consistent incnase in nuclear p65(RelA) which binds to an IL-2 promoter NF-KB site probe in gel shifi assays. The nuclear p65(RelA):p50 ratio, as determined by gel shift assay. is significantly greater than 1.0 in activated Thl clones. In contrast, TCR signaling does not induce a significant increase in nuclear 65(RelA) in Th2 cells, and the p65(RelA):p50 ratio is consistentfy less than 1 .O. Western blot analyses indicate that there are equivalent amounts of cytoplasmic p65(RelA) in Thl and Th2 cells, but TCR signaling is not efficiently coupled to nuclear translocation of p65 in Th2 cells. Additional studies suggest differences between TCR and cytokine effects on IKB and differences in IKB expression between Thl and Th2 clones.

body_text.text: Our studies addresing cytokine gene expression in naive T cells as they undergo subset differentiation indicate independent regulation of each cytokine over time. Expression of IFN-y mRNA in IL12 plus antigen stimulated naive T cells occurs early, within 6 hours. In contrast, expression of IL-4 mRNA in IL-4 plus antigen stimulated naive T cells does not occur until 48 hours. IL-2 mRNA is equivalently expressed in both L-4 and IL-12 treated populations during the primary stimulation. No consistent differences are found in NFAT. AP1, NFKB, or NFIL-2A activation between Thl and Th2 differentiating populations. We have identified a sequence in the murine IL-4 promoter which shares features of Stat6 (IL-4NAF) binding sites previously described in other promoters. Gel shift assays using a probe with this sequence indicate that it does bind purified Stat6 but not Stat4 or Stat5, and it also binds Stat6 found in the nuclei of IL-4 stimulated T cells. We have also demonstrated that this site can mediate IL4 induced transcription of a linked reporter gene. Gel shift and Western blot studies indicate that Stat6 is induced early in the IL4 mated naive T cells, and activation (i.e. nuclear presence) is maintained for over 48 hours. We have also demonstrated autocrine Stat6 activation in these Th2differentiating populations. Stat6 can be activated in Th 1 populations by IL-4 treatment, consistent with our fmding that L-4 promotes a switch from Thl to Th2 phenotypes. Thus prolonged Stat6 activation is the only transcription-regulation event which we have idenWied which distinguishes Thl and Th2 differentiation of naive T cells. Studies are underway to further define the functional effects of Stat6 binding to the IL-4 promoter and the possible interaction of Stat6 with other transcription factors.

A basic rcquircmcnt for normal functioning of the immune system is continuous recirculation of lymphocytes between blood and lymphatic tissues. It allows a closc contact betwecn lymphocytes and their cognatc antigens and other cell types necdcd to create effective immune reponse. In lymphoid organs, lymphocytes leave the blood by adhcring to specialized vesscls called high endothelial venules (HEV) because of the morphological appearance. of their endothelial cells. Binding of migrating lymphocytes to endothelial cells is mediated by scquential intcraction between lymphocytc surface molccules and thcir endotheial cell counter-rcccptors. There are at least four steps in this cascade: 1) recognition dctccted as rolling of thc lymphocyte on the endothelial cell, 2) activation, 3) tight adhesion, and 4) transmigration. In physiological conditions two functionally distinct systems mediate lymphocyte traffic to peri;.;leral lymph nodes and mucosa-associated lymphatic tissucs. in inflammatory situations lymphocytes together with other leukocytes migrate to sites of inflammation. Inflamed skin and synovium arc tissues to which lymphocyte homing has been studied most. The recent rcsults show that the mechanisms controlling lymphocyte entrance to inflamed skin and synovium are different from each other and also distinct from those mediating the extravasation to peripheral lymph nodes or mucttsa-associatcd lymphoid tissucs. An important molecular pair mediating lymphocytc traffic to inflamed skin is cutaneous lymphocyte antigen-1 (CJA-1) that binds to its endothelial cell ligand E-sclcctin, Moreover, periphcral lymph node addrcssin (PNAd) is induced and vascular adhesion protcin-1 PAP-1) is upregulated in inflamcd skin endothelium, and they both sccm to be important in mediating lymphocyte intcraction with vascular endothelium in inflamed skin. In animal models, lymphocyte homing into inflamcd skin has been shown to involve also lymphocytc function associatcd antigcn-1 (LFA-l), very late activation antigcn-4 (VLA-4) and CD44. Participation of thesc molccules belonging to different molecular families in lymphocytc homing into inflamed skin suggest that at least three distinct, but most likely overlapping, adhesion mcchanisms (CLA-1 -E-selcctin; L-selectin -PNAd; unknown lymphocytc rcccptor -VAP-1) arc involvcd in rclatively early phases of the multistep cascade resulting in lymphocytc extravasation into the cutancous sites. Moreover, integrins &FA-1, VLA-1) may be functioning during thc f i r m adhcsion phase. The exact location of CD44 in the cascade is most speculative. Based on the publishcd results from other systems, both the rolling phasc and activation stcp are possible.

Lung harbours significant numbers of intravenously injected lymphocytes that form a massive marginating pool while failing to migrate in large numbers into thc interstitial and hronchoalveolar spaces. Very little is known about the molccular intcractions functioning in margination or homing into the lung. In any w c , thc phenotype of pulmonary T cells is strikingly diffcrcnt from the phenotype of the T cells selectively migrating into the skin, and the data gathcrcd so far indicatc that lcukocytc trafficking into the lung has some unique characteritics. It is possible that the lung-sccking leukocytcs arc not apablc of rolling in the capillary bed of the lung and therefore, the molecules of the multi-stcp cascadc work simultaneously rather than scqcentially thcrc.

Anti-inflammatory therapies aimcd at to block the functions of homing-associated antigens have in many experimental scttings given promising results. Indentification of the optimal target molecules also in the skin and the respiratory tract is fcasiblc for future efforts to develop new anti-adhcsivc drugs to control inflammations in these locations.

Most cases of occupational rhinitis (OR) are caused by organic substances, but some chemicals can also cause OR. The most important causes of OR are animal dander, flours, wood dust, textile dust, food, spices, storage mites, enzymes, latex, and various chemicals. A patient suffering fiom rhinitis symptoms may have OR, if: 1) the rhinitis symptoms are connected to work, 2) the patient has been exposed to allergens or irritating fhctors at work, 3) other than an occupational cause of rhinitis has been excluded, and 4) a provocation test (PT) confirms the causality between the disease and the exposure.

Diagnosis of OR: The diagnosis of OR must be better confirmed than in allergic rhinitis of other etiology, as a diagnosis of occupational disease often means many changes to an employee. The diagnosis methods depend on the symptoms (immediate or delayed type) and the allergens. A carehl exposure history has to be taken and differential diagnosis has to be done. Skin prick and RAST tests are important. Spirometry and histamine provocation are often needed if bronchial hyperreactivity is suspected. A provocation test (PT) is required to confirm the diagnosis. Different provocations are used in the diagnosis of occupational rhinitis: nasal, chamber and work PTs. The nasal and chamber PTs are used to diagnose immediate or late reactions. Depending on the exposure time, the work PT can be used to register either immediate, late or chronic responses. Nasal PT: A nasal PT is used when the allergen to be tested is of organic origin. Different ways to perform the nasal PT have been reported. In our Institute we place the provocation material bilaterally onto the fronto-topical surface of the inferior turbinate.

A patient undergoes nasal PTs with different test materials on consecutive days. Each test series is started with placebo. The test is done single-blinded, so that the patient does not know which provocation material is tested until all tests have been done. The choice of test material is based on the patient history, and skin prick and RAST tests.

Chamber and work PT: In the case of suspected OR, a chamber PT is used when different chemicals are tested. The PT can also be done at the patient's workplace. In these two PTs not only the nasal status but also the response of the pharynx, larynx and lungs can be registered.

Response recording: The changes in rhinorrhea and blockage of both nasal cavities are registered. Status and symptom scores (e.g. visual analogue scale) are used. Some patients tend to overestimate their symptoms. This means that some objective measurements should be included in the response recording. The change in nasal ainvay resistance, using rhinomanometry, can be measured. The change in the nasal geometry can be registered with acoustic rhinometry. Nasal peak expiratory flow is also sometimes used as well as nasal cytology, mucous membrane biopsies, or tryptase and other mediator measurements. Conclusions: 1) most of the diagnosed cases of OR are immediate type allergic rhinitis, 2) the status change is most important in the registration of the response to the PT, but also an objective measurement should be included in the response recording, 3) nasal symptoms and status changes caused by various industrial exposures are underestimated. 060 readings increases the reliance on individual readings which might be affected by exercise,late waking etc.,reduces the measured diurnal variation, and reduces the diagnostic sensitivity of the record. Workers with severe occupational asthma may however, show obvious work-related changes even with very small numbers of readings per day. Differences between work days and rest days are accentuated by plotting the lung function as a dakly maximum, mean and minimum which can be assessed either visually or by using a computer-aided scoring system. We have developed such a system (0ASYS)which plots the record in an interpretable manner and provides a score based on either a discriminant or neural net analysis, achieving a sensitivity of about 85% and a specificity of around 95%. The quality of the records is the single most important determinant of a good test. Records can be prefabricated and the quality of measurement is less than is ideally achieved in a 1aboratory.In the future,logging meters with quality control of data input in real time are likely to improve the quality of the data.In our experience, good quality readings are obtained in about 50% of workers after postal instruction and in a further 30% of workers after a clinic visit,leaving 20% of workers who never provide adequate readings.

body_text.section: 1 SERIAL MEASUREMENTS OF LUNG FUNCTION AT WORK AND AT HOME IN THE DIAGNOSIS OF OCCUPATIONAL ASTHMA

body_text.text: Occupational asthma can usually be strongly suspected from the history of deterioration of symptoms in relationship to exposure at work and improvement while away from exposure. It is important to confirm the diagnosis before serious decisions about relocating a worker or altering the workplace are made. Serial measurements of lung function in relationship to work exposure are the most appropriate first step in the diagnosis, provided the reactions at work are not catastrophic (in which case carefully controlled bronchial provocation testing is safer). If occupational asthma exists, there should be measurable changes in lung function related to exposure to the offending agent. The problem is in distinguishing these changes due to exposure from those due to diurnal variation and the major confounding factors of infection, treatment and the dayto-day non-specific precipitants of asthma. To overcome these many confounding factors, records need to be made at times when the treatment does not change and when respiratory infections are absent. results are obtained from approximately 2 hourly readings of lung function from waking to sleeping with initial records lasting 4 The iesults of the Prcventivc Allcrgy Trcatment Study (the P.A T. study)@) showing preventive aspccts in the devclopnient of asthma childrcn suffcring from allergic rhinitis give a new challcnge in the treatment ff patients with allergic rhinitis. Whether spccific allcrgen injection immunotherapy is effectivc and safe in the treatment of allergic diseases is no more qucstionnable, S.I.T. has become to a ncw phasc. This ncw phase regarding thc prcvcntive aspects of S.I.T. is a great challenge for all doctors treating children with IgE-mediated allergic disorders. S.I.T. is effective in selected patients; effccicncy must always be b l a n d against possible sidc-cffccts (2) . body_text.section: THE DOUBLE-BLIND PLACEBO-CONTROLLED FOOD CHALLENGE I S AN OPTION IN CLINICAL PRACTICE

body_text.text: Background. The optimal diagnostic procedure of cow milk allergy has not been determined, but double-blind placebo controlled food challenge (DBPCFC) is considered the gold standard.
body_text.section: THE DOUBLE-BLIND PLACEBO-CONTROLLED FOOD CHALLENGE I S AN OPTION IN CLINICAL PRACTICE

body_text.text: Aim. To assess parental perception of the clinical procedure to diagnosis of cow milk allergy. Subjects and Methods. Parents of 265 patients, mean (95 % Cl) age 21 (20-23) mo, subjected to DBPCFC (n=l 10) or open cow milk challenge (n=155) were interviewed with a questionnaire 13 (12-14) mo later. Specific questions were asked on the time consumed, credibility of the diagnosis, and the overall response by the parents was ratcd as with thanks, all negative, both positive and negative or no comment. Family history was positive for atopy in 5 1 %, total IgE was 32 (24 -43) kU/L, cow milk RAST positive in 36 %, and skin prick test in 3 1 %. Results. The two groups were equal in response rate (68 %) as well as cow milk specific RAST and skin pick test. The DBPCFC resulted in fewer diagnoses of cow milk allergy, i.e. was less often positive (x2=4.0, ~4 . 0 4 ) .
body_text.section: THE DOUBLE-BLIND PLACEBO-CONTROLLED FOOD CHALLENGE I S AN OPTION IN CLINICAL PRACTICE

body_text.text: Interestingly, regardless of challenge result, the DBPCFC was more credible to the parents (x2=7.12, y0.007).
body_text.section: THE DOUBLE-BLIND PLACEBO-CONTROLLED FOOD CHALLENGE I S AN OPTION IN CLINICAL PRACTICE

body_text.text: Conclusion. The DBPCFC is not considered by the parents as overly laborious and the diagnosis does become morc credible. The DBPCFC should be considercd an option when positive challenge results in elimination of an essential food such as cow milk. The clinical and pathological analysis o f deaths of asthmatics in St. Petersburg for 21-year period was done. 29 children died, the mortality rate before 1984 was 0 -0,2 per 100, OOO of children population / the mean for 10 years -0,075 /, for the period 1985 -1995 -0 -035 / the mean -0.2 /. In all the cases the diagnosis of asthma was confirmed by autopsy and clinico-anatomical parallels were determined. 65% of deaths occurred on the t o p of severe asthmatic status. There were no deaths outside medical institutions before 1986, after 1986 they comprised 45% including deaths "with inhaler in hands". Possible medical and social causes of severe asthma course and fatal outcomes in observed group of children are analysed and discussed in details.

During rcCcnt ycar the development of sevcnl assays, for the unique measurcmcnt of thc activity in vivo of various inflammatory cells, have been developed. These included assays for thc rcflection of cosinophil activity such as ECP (eosinophil cationic protein), EXP (eosinophil protein-x) and EPO (eosinophil peroxidase). For the assay of neutrophil activity onc can usc elastase, HNL (human neutrophil lipocalin) or MPO (myeloperoxidase) and for the assay of mast cell activity, tryptase, Assays for monocytes/macrophages include cytokines such as TNFa, IL-6 but also lysozyme, although these protcins may also be produced by other cells. The soluble receptors for IL-2 and E-selection may be used as quite specific markers of T-lymphocyte and endothelial cell activity, respectively. In addition to thcsc cell markers the assay of several cytokines such as IL-8, GM-CSF, G-CSF, IFN-y is possible and of potential intcrcst in allergy and asthma. Measurement of inflammation markers could be made in blood i.e. plasma or serum or in any other body fluid.

me rationale for the use of inflammation markers is severalfold. One is the objective assessment of the inflammatory activity of the disease, since this is notoriously difficult in many of our patients and since current methods often are very insensitive or not at all affcctcd by the inflammatory process.

Annthcr is the diagnostic use of inflammation markcrs, since the knowlcdgc of thc involvement of various inflammatory components may enable us to make morc finc tuned diagnosis of our patients and possibly identify subgroups within certain diagnostic entities, which may have a bcaring on trcatmcnt stratcgics. Still another is the pathophysiological insight provided by the knowlcdgc of the quantitative and qualitative aspects of the components involved The current knowledge of the usc of inflammation markers for the above purposes is still fairly limitcd and rcstrictcd to a few markcrs and certain areas. The currently most studied marker in allergy and asthma is ECP in serum and increased levels are related to the disease seventy in asthma and to allergcn cxposurc. It is also valuable to use ECP measurements in the monitoring of anti-inflammatory treatment in both children and adults. Indeed the complicancc of the patients in this respect may bc followed with serum-measurements of ECP. Another interesting possibility is thc usc of ECP in the prediction of asthma exacerbations. Especially in small children the measurements in inflammatory markers in blood may be difficult. Thercforc dcmonstration of EPX in urine as a possible alternative deserves some attention. Thc experience of using of EPO is still very limited, but available data indicate that EPO discrimiilatcs bctter between allergic and non-allergic asthma than do ECP. Neutrophil markcrs such as MPO have shown somev,hat clcvatcd levels in serum in asthmatics, which could mean that thc circulating neutrophils are primed in these patients. The othcrwise most useful property of these markcrs is thc discrmination betwcen acute infcctions of viral and bacterial causcs. 'This was espccially clear for HNL, which showed a sensitivity and spccificity in this rcspcct of about 95%. The marker of mast cells, tryptasc, has so far mostly been uscd to diagnos anaphylactic cpisodcs, but with a better sensitivity of the assay It should be a useful marker in asthma. Scrum lcvcls of sohiblc IL-2 receptor has been shown to be elcvatcd in asthma, but its clinical valuc still has to bc proven.

Tlic usc inflammation markers is still at its infancy, but the rapidly expanding knowlcdge of the interpretation of the results in clinical terms will undoubtedly lay the grounds for the sound clinical use of these markers and include them in everyday managcmcnt of patients with asthma and allergy.

body_text.text: The non selective phosphodiesterase inhibitor, theophylline has long been recognized as a drug of use in the treatment of airway diseases such as asthma. Traditionally this drug has been suggested to act as a bronchodilator. Recent evidence however has suggested that theophylline can have effects as an anti-inflammatory agent. Theophylline has been reported to inhibit the release of inflammatory mediators from a variety of inflammatory and immunocompetent cells including alveolar macrophages, neutrophils. eosinophils, mast cells and Tlymphocytes"'. Additionally, theophylline has been shown in experimental animals to reduce eosinophil infiltration into the airways induced by allergen and the levels of eosinophil derived peroxide in BAL fluid (2). These effects have also now been demonstrated with selective PDE IV inhibitors suggesting that this action of theophylline may be related to inhibition of phosphodiesterase (3). Recent clinical evidence has also shown that theophylline can inhibit both eosinophil and lymphocyte trafficking into the airways of asthmatics following allergen exposure (4). Furthermore, recent data have shown that theophylline withdrawel leads to a worsening of asthma, even in patients taking glucocorticosleroids (5). These results suggest that theophylline should be considered as more than a bronchodilator substance and demonstrates that High ratcs of road !I I c t n i y i v r~l ylmonary function an,! incrwscd rcspiratory symptoms in children (4) in Munich. The downfall of the Soviet empire in Europe has opened the formerly socialist countries of Central and Eastern Europe to epidemiological studies. The prevalence of allergic diseases among children and young adults is low in t h e e countries with a life style which is similar in many respects to that prevailing in Western Europe 30-40 ycars ago. It is not known whether "western lifc style" i s associatcd with an introduction of new unknown adjuvants enhancing sensitisation, or whether these is a lack of factors that are necessary for the induction of tolerance.

The likelihood of developing allergic disease in an individual is not constant over time, even if the general propensity is genetically determined. Thus there secms to be a period in early life during which an infant is particularly susceptible to sensitisation. Variations in individual susceptibility to sensitisation over time may also partly be explained by the presence and absence of repiratory tract infection. The role of infections in the respiratory tract as risk factors for the development of childhood allergic disease and asthma is complex, however. It is wcll established that infections may trigger and aggravate asthma in already sensitised individuals and that infections incrcase bronchial hyperreactivity. Recent studies suggest, however, that respiratory infcctions could modify primary immune rcsponses to allergens and reduce the likelihood of sensi t isa t ion. The environment has undcrgonc major changcs. The discussion on the possible impact of the various enivironmental changes on the incedence of asthma and other allcrgies has mostly bcen limitcd to the possible effects of a deteriorating air quality, poorly ventilated houses and a increased exposure to certain allergens, notably house dust mites. "Endovironment" is much more than emissions from traffic and exposure to mites, however. Urbanisation has lcad to major changes in habits, thc food that wc eat arc in many respects diffcrcnt than only a few decades ago, the intestinal microbial flora has undergone changcs, ncw building materials and methods for construction have bccn introduccd, the homes arc larger dwellings, there are many new chemical compounds at home and the life style has changed with more time spent indoors and extensive travelling and cxposurc to ncw environments. The concept of "life stylc" should therefore be expanded considerably.

An understanding of the role of cnvironmental factors has rcccntly becomc complicated by some rcccnt observations. Air pollution is a major problem in many formerly socialistic countries in central and eastern Europe, yet the prevalence of atopy among childrcn is much lower than in western Europe. For example, the prevalence of positive skin prick tests is much lower in Eastcm Germany, Estonia and Poland than it is in Western Germany and Sweden. Mirroring the observed diffcrcnces in skin prick tcst positivity in an urban and rural area of Sweden, the prevalence of at least one positive skin prick test was significantly higher in Tallinn, an industrialised coastal city than in Tartu, which is an inland university town. Thus although air pollution docs scem to play a role in the devclopmcnt of atopy, other factors conncctcd with wcstem lifc stylc arc much more important. Thc naturc of thesc factors is unknown. Thc hypothesis that early childhood is a period of particular susccptibility to environmental influences and the onset of the "atopic march" is supportcd by studies showing that the large differcnccs between Eastern and Western Germany in the prevalence of scnsitisation to inhalant allergens are limited to the age groups born after 1961. Vcry reccntly similar data were obtained in a comparative study between two university towns in Estonia and Swcdcn.

In addition to the intriduction of many ncw chcmicals in the environment, there have been many changcs in lifc stylc in industrialised countries over the past decades, The type of foods eaten has changed dramatically with the introduction of ncw industrial products with numerous additivcs. Evcn frcsh food items differ in many respects from those available only a few decades ago. As an example, by genetic manipulation and use of various chemical compounds the storage time of food has been much prolonged, often allowing a shelf life e.g. apples for months. Virtually nothing is known regarding the possible influence on childhood allergy of such changes in the diet.

Even if all the known environmental risk factors arc takcn together thcy cannot explain the large geographic differences in the prevalence of allergy. The conclusion from a broad compilation of what is known regarding tiggers of allergy is that we cannot identify which environmental factors that are the major reason for the largc incrcasc in the prcvalcnce in recent years. The future search for significant environmental factors should be direct towards other areas that have not yct bccn cxplorcd. Future rcscarch should be truly interdisciplinary and "life style" should be given a broad interpretation.

The self-reported prevalence of asthmatic symptoms and associated early childhood factors was studied among 9163 schoolchildren aged 13-14 years in four regions of Finland, as part of the intcmational ISAAC study.

The 66 schools included in the study were randomly selected from the Helsinki area, 'hrku and Pori county, Kuopio county and southern part of Lapland county. In addition to the ISAAC Written and video questionnaires, children were asked about their smoking habits and their parents were sent a detailed questionnaire on risk factors for respiratory diseases. Response rates among children were over 94% in all four areas, but ranged between 64% (Helsinki) and 89% (Turku) among parents.
The self-reported prevalence of wheezing during the previous 12 months according to the written questionnaire was 13% in Kuopio, 17% in Helsinki, 14% in n r k u and 15% in Lapland.
The respective prevalence for any wheezing in the video qucstionnaire were 1096, ll%, 1246, and lo%, and of doctor diagnosed asthma 4%, 646, 7%, and 6%.

Having more siblings was associated with lower prevalence of doctor diagnosed asthma. Also, children attending day-care during the first 3 years of lifc tended to have less asthma. Analyses were adjusted for age, sex, area, and atopy of the parents and siblings. Parent's socioeconomic status was not associated with asthma.

In conclusion, we found that thc rcgional diffcrcnccs in the prevalence and severity of childhood asthma in Finland arc small, but the prevalence may be lower in Eastcrn Finland. The high prcvalcnce of asthma symptoms in Helsinki may bc due to the fact that the survey in Helsinki was done during the pollcn season. The observed prevalence of asthma was lower in Finland than in otlicr wcstcm countries. The finding that thc vidco qucstionnaire gave lower prevalence than thc written questionnaire is in contrast to findings from other countrics and suggests that using translations of the word 'wheezing' in Finnish questionnaires produccs internationally incomparable results.

Our findings of decreased risk of asthma among childrh with several siblings conforms with earlier reports. Also children attcnding a day-care during the first 3 years of lifc tcndcd to have less aahma. A possible explanation is a protective role of respiratory infections in early childhood on the risk of asthma.

A good inhaler thus should deliver a large dose to the lungs, with a concomitant low oropharyngeal deposition Different inhalers show large variations in the degree of lung deposition and each combination of drug and device is a unique combination. Caution should be exercised when extrapolating the outcome of one combination from other combinations of drug and device. Lung deposition for dry powder inhalers (DPIs) ranges from 10 to 30 %, with Turbuhaler' at the upper end of the range and most other DPIs at around 10 YO. pMDIs also vary in lung deposition; some pMDIs give 15-20% while others deliver 10-15% ofthe nominal dose to the lungs. A high lung, and a low orophmyngeal, deposition optimises the balance between desired effects in the lung and undesired local or systemic side e m s . Mucosal exudation of plasma is a specific inflammatoryinduced tissue (microvascular) response rcflccting inflammation in different types of airway diseases. This process is dertermined by the spccific ability of the subepithelial microvessels (endothelial cells of the post-capillary vcnulcs) to respond with increased pcrmeability on inflammatory stimulation resulting in extravasation of plasma in the lamina proparia and thc subscqucnt paraccllular cpithclial passage of bulk plasma into the airway lumen. FIGREF35.text: Allergic diseases are the result of abnormal responses of our immune system to environmental substances/allergens. Allergic reactions can be subdivided into two main varieties; the delayed hypersensitivity reaction like contact allergy to nickel and the immediate ,IgE-mediated form as in atopic asthma and hay fever. T lymphocytes are important effector cells in both forms. The first contact between an antigerdallergen and the antigenpresenting cells (APCs) is crucial in dictating the outcome of the immune response. Inhibition of the LFA-l/ICAM-1mediated interactions between APCs and T cells during sensitization to an allergen will induce long-term allergenspecific unresponsiveness(Scheynius et al. J Immunol 156: 1804, 1996). The route for introducing an allergen is also important since APCs from different tissues have the capacity to favor either cellular or humoral immune responses by influencing T cell cytokine production (Everson et al. J Lekoc Biol59:494, 1996). CD4+ T lymphocytes can be classified into functionally distinct subsets on the basis of their cytokine production (Mosmann et al. Annu Rev Immunol 7:145, 1989). Thl cells secrete interleukin (1L)-2 and interferon (1FN)-y and are essential in the host defence against intracellular pathogens. Th2 cells produce IL-4 and IL-5 and are important in antibodymediated immune reactions and in the defence against parasites. IL-4 stimulates B cells to IgE production, while IL-5 stimulates eosinophils. When CD4+ T cells produce both types of cytokines, they are denoted Tho cells. Thl cells dominate in contact allergy whereas Th2 cells are more prominent in IgEmediated allergic reactions. However, the analysis on biopsy specimens and of allergen-reactive T cell clones isolated From peripheral blood or target organs have indicated that there is not only a mixture of different Th-type cells but also that Thl cells are able to produce some IL-4 (Haanen et al. J Exp Med 174583,1991) and Th2 cells can secrete low levels of IL-2 and IFN-y (Yssel et al. J Immunol 148:738, 1992).

Kanerva Section of Dermatology, Finnish Institute of Occupational Health, Helsinki, Finland.Aims: To review the current understanding of occupational contact urticaria (OCU), and give stiltistical data on OCU. Methods: The diagnosis of OCU should includc an appropriate history, combined with specific skin tests, IgB determinations (e.g., RASTs), provocation tests, RAST inhibition tests. immunoblotings etc.Results: Altogether 815 cases of OCU were reported to thc Finnish Register of Occupational Diseases during 1990-1Y94, compared with 1944 caSes of occupational allergic contact dermatitis. Accordingly, the total number of occupational allergic contact dermatoses was 2759,29.5 % being contact urticaria and 70.5 8 being allergic contact dermatitis. Occupational contact urticaria was much more common in women (70 %) than in men (30 8). The six most common causes of contact urticaria were (1) cow dander (44.4 %), (2) natural rubber latex (23.7 %), (3) flour, grains and feed(1 1.3 a),(4)   handling of foodstuffs(3.1 a),(5)  industrial enzymes(1.7 %)    and (6) decorative plant$(1.6 8). The occupations with the highest numbers of occupational contact urticaria were ( I ) farmers, (2) domestic animal attendants, (3) bakers, (4) nurses, (5) chefs and (6) dental assistants. The ranking list of the most common occupations with occupational contact urticaria per 100 000 employed workers was as follows: ( I ) bakers (1 40.5 cues per 100,000 employed persons), (2) preparers of processed food, (3) dental assistants, (4) veterinary surgeons, ( 5 ) domestic animal attendants, (6) farmers and silviculturalists. Low-molecular weight chemicals caused very few cases of occupational contact urticaria, the most common being Z-ethylhexyl acrylate (5 cases).

Childrcn in East Germany livcd in smaller, morc crowded homcs, in larger families, and wcrc more exposcd to many othcr children in day care setting (and thus to viral infections) much earlicr than thcir countcrparts in thc Wcst side of the country.
